fields.description:
Currently the userdata field on the instance detail page does not display any userdata information since not supported by API.

It'd be better off to remove the userdata field since a user would expect some data to be displayed if the userdata was specified for the instance. Leaving the userdata alway blank seems to be serving no purpose and ends up rather inducing confusion.

Plus, it was discovered that the when the instance is stopped, userdata can be edited, which is a feature on AWS management console. However, in our case, since no original userdata is shown, there is a possibility of making a mistake of overwriting the entire userdata, which is verified on AWS.

See the attachment.

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Instance+detail+page+-+refreshed
fields.summary: Display user data for instances and launch configs. Support modifying user data for stopped instances.

comments.body: I think we should keep the functionality, but let the user know they will be replacing the existing user data blindly.
It was verified, on AWS using eucaconsole, that specifying userdata when starting a stopped instance would overwrite the entire userdata with the new data.

I guess this ticket should've been two separate tickets, one is to remove the userdata field on the instance detail page since it always shows empty field, which creates confusion when the userdata was specified, and the second issue is that specifying the userdata when re-starting a stopped instance, it overwrites the previous userdata.
[~kyolee]: We don't have a userdata field on the user detail page; updated ticket to "instance detail page"

The field currently shows disabled unless the instance is stopped, what should happen instead is the field (and label) should not show at all unless the instance is stopped. 

And, we can have a message when they put something here too that they are overwriting the existing user data if there was any, when they submit.

Issue 1. The userdata field is always showing an empty, disabled field whether the userdata actually contains data or not.

Issue 2. After an EBS instance is stopped, the userdata field will be enabled to allow the field to be edited. In such case, rather than editing, the userdata will be overwritten with the new data.

To clarify the issue 2, one AWS management console, the original userdata is displayed on the editor, thus allowed to be updated, not overwritten.

However, since retrieving userdata is not supported by API, on eucaconsole we cannot obtain the existing userdata associated with the instance, thus showing empty field. For this reason, we currently do not have a way of allowing user to "update" the userdata.

UPDATE: we have learned that the API support for retrieving userdata has been implemented in Eucalyptus. Thus, it is a bug that we do not show the userdata and allows user to overwrite it rather than updating it.

[~jloza] If we are to display user data, and if the user data is a file that isn't printable, we need to do something reasonable. It is perfectly valid to use a binary file for user data and I've seen that euca2ools shows the file directly, which we probably shouldn't do, but I suppose that's an option.

[root@h-35 admin]# euca-describe-instance-attribute  --user-data i-636d4201
userData	i-636d4201
?PNG

IHDR^?+wsRGB???bKGD?C?	pHYs

                            ??tIME?

                                   ?H\?"tEXtCommentCreated with GIMP on a Mac??wClIDATx???_h??????܌s?K3?'QBW??2?n??4+?2?????C?)e?H??Uu!
?D?I?

Based on this new info that we *can* get this via API, here is what we should do:

1) on instance detail page, when instance is *not stopped* we should provide a show/hide link to display the user data (hide by default)
2) when stopped the user data should be displayed in an editable field, and the user can update it there
3) If user data is not printable, we need to display in a manner consistent with how AWS console displays. 

Thanks!

[~dkavanagh]: We may be able to leverage https://github.com/ahupp/python-magic to guess the content type from the contents of the file, assuming the API doesn't capture or provide the file name of an uploaded userdata file.

I've included python-magic which works well. It includes a new dependency in setup.py, but no new binary requirement on CentOS. It adds another item to the brew install which has been noted in the README in the PR.
I've implemented lazy-loading of the user data on the instance detail page. If the contents is a form of text, that will be displayed in the user data text area at all times (and editable when the instance is stopped).
I've attached a screen shot to show how the aws console handles binary user data. It simply shows it and lets the user edit it, which I don't feel is helpful (or particularly good UX). I'm able to display a helpful message about what the binary file contains like "PNG image data, 350 x 350, 8-bit/color RGBA, non-interlaced" or "Java Jar file data (zip)".
I wonder if we did display a binary user data description, shouldn't we also provide a text field and "browse" button?
[~jloza] in cleaning up branches, I noticed there is some work on this already. I'm adding this to sprint 1. We can push to sprint 2 as needed.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/824
Jenkins passed, UX passed. Assigning to [~kyolee] for code review/merge

[~dkavanagh] When checked out the branch, the user-data field on the instance detail page is still showing as a grey textbox with no user-data being displayed. See the attachment above.

And, also we should be looking into enabling the 'enter' key to be clicked when typing in user-data directly on the text box at launch time. It's not UX-friendly that the 'enter' key is disabled on the user-data inputbox on the instance launch wizard.

The error message displayed on Pyramid:

  File "/root/seeds/eucaconsole/eucaconsole/views/instances.py", line 652, in instance_userdata_json
    type = magic.from_buffer(unencoded, mime=True)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 132, in from_buffer
    return m.from_buffer(buffer)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 65, in from_buffer
    self._thread_check()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 81, in _thread_check
    raise Exception('attempting to use libmagic on multiple threads will '
Exception: attempting to use libmagic on multiple threads will end in SEGV.  Prefer to use the module functions from_file or from_buffer, or carefully manage direct use of the Magic class


Installed on CentOS.

I'll look at these things. 
According to :https://bitbucket.org/nicfit/eyed3/issue/47/libmagic-throws-thread-error-when-used
This should have been fixed in 0.7.5 and pypi has 1.0
Can I ask what you did to get this error? Were you doing simultaneous requests?

Agree with [~kyolee]'s comment above, Enter key should be usable in the user data text box, it should be able to start a new line. Need to be sure it works that way (which it should as part of the multi-line text box widget) and doesn't activate the default button. That is a separate issue from this bug, though, and a separate bug should be filed for that, please, [~kyolee].
On an instance that does have user data, the grey (non-editable) text box shows up with the user data in it. Did your instance have user data?

Yes. The instance was started with user-data, as well as the case where the instance was stopped and started with user data added. In both cases, the user data wasn't displayed on the user data field, left with an empty grey box.

Sent from my iPhone

OK, this is odd... I am looking at an editable text area with existing user data (on a stopped instance). I'm able to press 'return' and get a new line. What browser were you using? I'm testing in FF.
I also just tested the newline and gray box issues in Chrome and found no problems.

If you could pls retry after clearing cache. This feature does require the latest javascript, so if that isn't fetched, it will fail. Perhaps we could get [~jloza] to check it out as well since I'm not finding the failure.
I am using chrome with cache cleared and I am not getting a new line like I should when I hit enter.
yea, this is odd. On the instance detail page, I'm able to hit return in the text area, but not on the launch instance wizard. If I can find the difference, I'll make sure it works throughout.
That would be super awesome. Thanks, [~dkavanagh]

This listener is blocking the linebreaks universally;
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/develop/eucaconsole/static/js/pages/instance_launch.js#L71-L75
Looks like [~kgill] added it in this commit: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/commit/6f8121e4c6651cf344872a5210e839cf3a256cd0

However, doing that on the window is too aggressive and has unintended consequences (like this). I think this is the same in the other places.

Yeah, this needs to be applied carefully rather than with a sledgehammer. I know we were trying to prevent form submit on enter for specific fields (I think this originally came up because clicking enter in the text entry field that allows you to directly enter an image ID was submitting the form when it shouldn't (really, it should activate the next button at that point, but I think the design of our wizard panels sees all the tabs as a single form, when things like the next button should be tied to a specific tab as the default button for that tab). On some other widgets and tabs, it actually should submit the form, and on yet other widgets (like multi-text entry fields) the widget definition (if Foundation has their act together) should allow Enter to do what its job of creating a new line and not activate the default button by design without requiring us to code any kind of override.

I made a change so that the image-id-input has a keydown listener and the tag editor sets keydown listener on it's two fields so that would be anywhere the tag editor is used.
In testing, I can now press enter in the user-data area (yay!). If I press enter in some other fields, I don't get a submit, but the image JSON re-loads (as seen in firebug), but the user doesn't really notice.
I'll apply this to the other places where user data is used (I think just launch_config_wizard and launch_more)
Dang, forgot to apply the user data GUI change to launch more... I'll do that next.
pls pass to kyo for code after UX checks

Looks awesome! newline works. The only thing that needs fixing is it really helps usability if, once a radio button is selected, the cursor goes into the associated widget. Such as, when they select enter text, the cursor automatically goes to the beginning of the multi-line text box and they can just start typing. 

Nice job, [~dkavanagh].

Tested on Chrome on OS X with the console server running on Centos 6, the user-data gets displayed only once. After the server errors out with the message below:

File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 132, in from_buffer
return m.from_buffer(buffer)
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 65, in from_buffer
self._thread_check()
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/python_magic-0.4.6-py2.6.egg/magic.py", line 81, in _thread_check
raise Exception('attempting to use libmagic on multiple threads will '
Exception: attempting to use libmagic on multiple threads will end in SEGV. Prefer to use the module functions from_file or from_buffer, or carefully manage direct use of the Magic class

I'm able to reproduce in CentOS and found this other project's solution to the problem:
https://bitbucket.org/nicfit/eyed3/src/d2b30b20c12cb1ae8061de9008e72940a89af23c/src/eyed3/utils/__init__.py#cl-64

Seems that python-magic is doing a pretty heavy-handed check on the threading and we can replace that with our own locking. Since gunicorn uses separate workers, the chance of blocking on the magic_lock would be pretty small so not worried about locks around that code.
I've introduced a fix that removes the magic thread checker and uses a lock around the magic code instead. It was taken (in spirit) from the link above.

The fix has been merged.

Tested the user-data display for newly launched instance as well as stopped and started instance.

Pure python or not, the magic library is still a new dependency that needs enumeration in packaging code.  I just added it to the spec file in eucaconsole-rpmspec commit {{a32445b}}, so things should begin working again starting with the next build.

Verified.  This is working.
{code}
